Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2011 03:39AM Merilee wrote: I am happy to report that I had a very nice experience with the RO. The first thing he did was reassure me that they were not going to make my hair fall out, make me radio active, make me nauseous, or burn me. I was a little surprised. He said that the worst it will get is that my top layer of skin may peel like an old sunburn might. I will be evaluated weekly to see if anything needs to be adjusted down and if I have any problems in between he will see me that day. They put me in a cat scan that has the capacity of a computer  lining up the beams so that they do not hit my heart, lungs or thyroid. Pretty nifty equipment. I will get 30 beams of healing light monday - friday. He does not want to start till the 25 of July to give my body time to regenerate itself after chemo. Then he revealed to me that he is a Cancer survivor- Ah ha he gets it Yippy! Two weeks of freedom, I won't know what to do with myself. lol

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2011 03:32AM Merilee wrote: Hi ladies, Just popping in from the April thread to check on  you all. Just finished 4 tc 2 weeks ago. A couple things. Green tea while on chemo is a no no. It has such strong anit oxidants that t can undermine the chemo. If you ask your onc about this he/she will confirm it Also for those sore fingertips, I got a hot wax machine and would put a nice oil on my finger tips then dip in the wax and leave it on ten minutes or so and it really helped. Clairiton taken with neulasta has helped many of us decrease side effects also. Naproxen is the best pain med for skeletal muscular pain. your doc can give you an rx. Wishing you healing thoughts Merilee

Posts.Title: Infection prior to chemo okay? Pats_Girl Pats_Girl

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2009 07:20PM Merilee wrote: My biopsy happened the same day I was in getting my mammogram results.  The surgeon was there to meet me and told me she did not like how the mammogram  looked and asked if she could take a sample right then.  She numbed me up and put a needle in and it was no big deal. I had my results from that in 2 days. It does seem like you have had some hasty advise.  I would strongly suggest getting the biopsy, then making any necessary decisions. I t is a big deal to remove a breast and that should not be taken so lightly by your medical professionals. That being said,  treatment has come a long way so even if it does turn out to be cancer, you will almost certainly survive. I would ask for a biopsy as soon as you can and get it behind you.  Waiting and uncertainty are the worst. Once I had a diagnosis I could make a plan and be proactive, that felt much better. Now, I am as healthy as a horse.

Posts.Title: 10 years ago at Christmas.... Gabrielle Mimidi

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 05:13PM - edited Dec 29, 2011 05:16PM by Merilee Funny this should come up now, here is something I wrote about this topic on my blog a few days ago. I think people are naturally curious. Most are also very gracious. When my hair was gone, and I would run into people who did not know I was on chemo, not one person dared mention my hair loss. I think for some, it was just to much reality, for others it elicited a fear that many woman have. The fear  that they themselves  may one day have to endure the side effects of cancer treatment. One devistating side affect  is hair loss, another is often the loss of one or both breasts. I remember getting out of the shower bald and breastless one day. I caught a glimpse of myself in the misty mirror. For just a moment I could see myself as a ghost. It was eerie and I said out loud " Holy shit Mer, you are beat up. " I replied to the ghost in the mirror " but I'm still standing mother f***er!" I realized that I had picked up the sailor language of my late brother who recently passed away from cancer. I laughed out loud and thanked him for inspiring toughness in me as a child sibling. I also notice just how much I looked like him, without my breasts and hair. I have always been a bit of a tom boy but this day, I felt like I was genderless. Just some creature transitioning through this world. I realized that much of what makes a woman feel feminine had been taken from me by the beast. Cancer has a way of stripping you down to your essence, which I found has very little to do with hair and boobs. Loosing my hair and breasts was humbling beyond words. No one ever thinks that such extreme things will happen to them and when you are wrong,  it is indeed traumatizing. Trauma changes your perspective and deepens your thoughts about the way you spend  your life.  I have always been  a nurturer and have mothered many kids in addition to my own. My favorite role in life is that of mother. The thought of my children being orphans  strikes a raw nerve in me that makes me cry every time I think of it. It also motivates me to work hard at wellness. It was key in my decision to take a sabbatical from work and try to tweak out a life that is more in keeping with my feminine motherly instincts. They say that when a person looses one of their senses, that the others perk up and make up for it. I dare say, that loosing some of the aspects of my femininity to the beast, has most definitely perked my mothering instincts. I have also learned that darkness is always balanced with light. This, I love.
Posts.Title: Gender Identity? MT1 sespebadger

Posts.Content: May 14, 2011 05:44AM Merilee wrote: I am on TC  My arsonal: Decadron Prilosec Phazime clairiton zofran imodium Naproxyn 500 biotene maylox atavan at night for sleep compazine on hand if needed senicot if needed eye drops for dry eyes lots of flavored water- drink! massage therapy counseling for the mental health coconut oil for moisture wax machine for dry hands and feet gold bond moistusrizing sanitizer for the purse Prep H if neeeded Desitin if needed I write down every thing I do because my brain goes to mush for a few days so I keep a little journal of how I am doing and what time I have taken meds. oh and one more thing- Fresh flowers  good for the "I love you/me" feeling

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2010 09:38AM Merilee wrote: Ladies, Having a mastectomy does not guarantee you will never have a recurrence. I had a Mastectomy in Jan of 09 and a recurrence in my arm pit in November of 09. Not trying to scare anyone just want you to know the facts while making decisions. They key thing here is that you catch it ealry. It is easy to treat if it has not moved to other parts of your body.
Posts.Title: The Waiting is the Worst... hopeful01 MBCR

Posts.Content: May 2, 2009 07:24PM Merilee wrote: I was shocked to learn that women who drink more than 2 drinks in a day increase their risk of breast cancer by 50%. Something to do with how the body metabolizes the sugar in booze.  I have not felt like a drink since reading that.

Posts.Content: May 6, 2009 11:23AM Merilee wrote: I used an ace bandage around my waste and tucked my drains under them to hold them up when I showered. I had a lot more movement than I expected and my body let me know when I was pushing to far. I would suggest moving important things off top shelves before your surgery.  It is hard to reach way up for a while.
Posts.Title: Questions about After Bilateral Mastectomy hlya lifegoeson

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 04:32PM Merilee wrote: If you have a lawyer I would just call and ask a few questions.  That way you know where you stand and what you can and can not ask for. It seems to me that you are right, it is your body. Good luck and please keep us informed about how it goes. This is of partivular interest to me as I am at odds with my Onc about my treatment as well. So much so that I am making an appointment with  another one. Also you may want to get a second opinion from another surgeon before you move forward.

Posts.Title: Does anyone get very sick after chemotherapy? Sohaila tougherthanithought

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 11:03AM Merilee wrote: I took this post to mean, take a look at your life and try to eliminate stress. I did not read any blame into it. I for one am taking steps to simplify my life and destress. This included throwing a few highly stressful people out of my life. I for one do believe that stress is a factor as I was under a ton of stress for a good long time before my diagnosis. I think it is one factor along with environmental toxins that are in our food and just about everywhere. I have not family history, & no genetic link. The reason to look at causes is not to kick yourself in the butt for not avoiding it, but to try our best to avoid anything that may be a factor in a recurrence.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 03:13PM Merilee wrote: I see, well I am sure that the medical professionals are thinking if it is something to be concerned about, then you want to know right away. The earlier things are caught the easier they are to treat. Also you want to know right away if it is nothing to be concerned about so that you can stop worrying. I went for my biopsy the same day I saw the doc, who happened to be a breast surgeon. I had a mammogram 6 months earlier that did not show anything up. I figured what ever it was would need surgery so that is why I when directly to her when I found the lump.
